1→# PRD
     2→
     3→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas - Product Requirements Document (PRD)
     4→
     5→**Version:** 1.0.0
     6→**Date:** 2025-12-06
     7→**Status:** Phase 1 MVP
     8→**Document Owner:** Architecture Team
     9→
    10→---
    11→
    12→## Table of Contents
    13→
    14→1. [Executive Summary](#1-executive-summary)
    15→2. [Functional Requirements](#2-functional-requirements)
    16→3. [Technical Requirements](#3-technical-requirements)
    17→4. [User Stories](#4-user-stories)
    18→5. [Acceptance Criteria](#5-acceptance-criteria)
    19→6. [Non-Functional Requirements](#6-non-functional-requirements)
    20→7. [Dependencies](#7-dependencies)
    21→8. [Out of Scope](#8-out-of-scope)
    22→
    23→---
    24→
    25→## 1. Executive Summary
    26→
    27→### 1.1 Product Vision
    28→
    29→**SizeWise HVAC Canvas** is a professional-grade, desktop-first HVAC design and estimation application that enables HVAC professionals to design ventilation systems, perform engineering calculations, and generate accurate bills of materials.
    30→
    31→### 1.2 Target Users
    32→
    33→| User Type | Description | Primary Use Cases |
    34→| --- | --- | --- |
    35→| **HVAC Estimator** | Prepares quotes for commercial HVAC projects | Create estimates, generate BOMs, export pricing sheets |
    36→| **HVAC Designer** | Designs ventilation systems for buildings | Layout ductwork, size equipment, verify airflow |
    37→| **Kitchen Ventilation Specialist** | Focuses on commercial kitchen exhaust systems | Design hood systems, calculate makeup air, meet code requirements |
    38→
    39→### 1.3 Phase 1 MVP Goals
    40→
    41→The Phase 1 MVP focuses on **air-side HVAC design** with these primary objectives:
    42→
    43→1. **Canvas-based design workspace** for drawing rooms, ducts, and equipment
    44→2. **Real-time HVAC calculations** for airflow, velocity, and pressure drop
    45→3. **Local-first architecture** with .sws file format for project persistence
    46→4. **Bill of Materials generation** with CSV export capability
    47→5. **PDF export** for professional documentation
    48→
    49→### 1.4 Success Metrics
    50→
    51→| Metric | Target | Measurement |
    52→| --- | --- | --- |
    53→| Project creation to first entity | < 30 seconds | User testing |
    54→| Canvas rendering at 500 entities | 60 fps | Performance benchmark |
    55→| File save/load reliability | 100% | Automated testing |
    56→| Calculation accuracy | ±1% of manual calculation | Validation testing |
    57→
    58→---
    59→
    60→## 2. Functional Requirements
    61→
    62→### 2.1 Dashboard (Project Management)
    63→
    64→### FR-DASH-001: Project Listing
    65→
    66→- Display all projects from configured project folder
    67→- Show project metadata: name, last modified date, entity count
    68→- Support sorting by: name, date modified (default: most recent first)
    69→- Cache project metadata in `.index.json` for fast loading
    70→
    71→### FR-DASH-002: Create Project
    72→
    73→- Create new blank project with user-specified name
    74→- Save as `.sws` file in project folder
    75→- Initialize with default project metadata and empty canvas state
    76→- Navigate to Canvas view upon creation
    77→
    78→### FR-DASH-003: Open Project
    79→
    80→- Open existing `.sws` file from project folder
    81→- Validate file schema before loading
    82→- Display error if file is corrupted or incompatible version
    83→- Navigate to Canvas view upon successful load
    84→
    85→### FR-DASH-004: Project Actions
    86→
    87→- **Archive**: Move project to `/archived` subfolder
    88→- **Delete**: Move to OS trash/recycle bin (not permanent delete)
    89→- **Duplicate**: Create copy with ” (Copy)” suffix
    90→- **Rename**: Update project name and filename
    91→
    92→### FR-DASH-005: Recent Projects
    93→
    94→- Track last 10 opened projects
    95→- Display as quick-access list on dashboard
    96→- Remove entries if file no longer exists
    97→
    98→---
    99→
   100→### 2.2 Canvas Interface

1→# Changelog
     2→
     3→All notable changes to the HVAC Canvas App will be documented in this file.
     4→
     5→The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/),
     6→and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).
     7→
     8→## [Unreleased]
     9→
    10→### Added
    11→- Comprehensive CI/CD pipeline with GitHub Actions
    12→- Integration and E2E testing infrastructure
    13→- FittingTool for HVAC fittings (elbows, tees, reducers, caps)
    14→- NoteTool for text annotations
    15→- Undo/Redo UI integration with keyboard shortcuts
    16→- Environment configuration validation
    17→- Auto-save functionality with debouncing
    18→- Project export to JSON and CSV formats
    19→
    20→### Changed
    21→- Improved test coverage from 40% to 70-75%
    22→- Enhanced Toolbar with undo/redo buttons
    23→- Updated vitest configuration for better coverage reporting
    24→
    25→### Fixed
    26→- React Hooks violation in Toolbar component (useCanUndo/useCanRedo)
    27→- Environment validation for production builds
    28→
    29→## Release Template
    30→
    31→When creating a new release, copy this template and fill in the details:
    32→
    33→```markdown
    34→## [X.Y.Z] - YYYY-MM-DD
    35→
    36→### Added
    37→- New features
    38→
    39→### Changed
    40→- Changes in existing functionality
    41→
    42→### Deprecated
    43→- Soon-to-be removed features
    44→
    45→### Removed
    46→- Removed features
    47→
    48→### Fixed
    49→- Bug fixes
    50→
    51→### Security
    52→- Security vulnerability fixes
    53→```
    54→
    55→## Version History
    56→
    57→<!-- Releases will be added here automatically -->
    58→
    59→---
    60→
    61→## Versioning Strategy
    62→
    63→**Semantic Versioning (X.Y.Z):**
    64→- **X (Major)**: Incompatible API changes, major features
    65→- **Y (Minor)**: Backward-compatible functionality additions
    66→- **Z (Patch)**: Backward-compatible bug fixes
    67→
    68→**Pre-release tags:**
    69→- `alpha`: Early testing, features incomplete
    70→- `beta`: Feature complete, but may have bugs
    71→- `rc`: Release candidate, ready for final testing
    72→
    73→**Examples:**
    74→- `v1.0.0` - First stable release
    75→- `v1.1.0` - Minor feature addition
    76→- `v1.1.1` - Bug fix
    77→- `v2.0.0-beta.1` - Beta for version 2.0.0
    78→
    79→## Release Process
    80→
    81→1. **Update CHANGELOG.md**
    82→   - Move changes from `[Unreleased]` to new version section
    83→   - Add release date
    84→   - Create new `[Unreleased]` section
    85→
    86→2. **Update version in package.json**
    87→   ```bash
    88→   cd hvac-design-app
    89→   npm version [major|minor|patch]
    90→   ```
    91→
    92→3. **Create git tag**
    93→   ```bash
    94→   git tag -a v1.0.0 -m "Release version 1.0.0"
    95→   git push origin v1.0.0
    96→   ```
    97→
    98→4. **GitHub Actions will automatically:**
    99→   - Build Tauri apps for all platforms
   100→   - Create GitHub release
   101→   - Upload installers
   102→   - Generate release notes
   103→
   104→5. **Verify release**
   105→   - Check GitHub Releases page
   106→   - Download and test installers
   107→   - Verify release notes are correct
   108→
   109→## Links
   110→
   111→- [Repository](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App)
   112→- [Issues](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/issues)
   113→- [Releases](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/releases)
   114→

entries.content:
I've read the spec and created a comprehensive implementation plan. Here's a summary:

## Implementation Plan Created

**Feature:** Populate empty README.md with project overview and quick links

### Summary of Findings

The project is **SizeWise HVAC Canvas** - a professional-grade desktop HVAC design and estimation application built with:
- **Tauri** (desktop runtime)
- **Next.js 14** with TypeScript
- **Zustand** (state management)
- **Zod** (validation)
- **Vitest & Playwright** (testing)

### Plan Structure: 3 Phases, 11 Subtasks

| Phase | Name | Subtasks | Status |
|-------|------|----------|--------|
| 1 | Research and Content Gathering | 2 | ✅ Completed |
| 2 | README Content Creation | 7 | Pending |
| 3 | Quality Assurance | 2 | Pending |

### Phase 2 Sections to Create:
1. **Header with badges** - CI status, license, platform support
2. **Project overview** - What it is, target users, value proposition
3. **Features showcase** - Canvas design, HVAC calculations, BOM, local-first
4. **Quick start** - Prerequisites, installation, running
5. **Tech stack** - All technologies with versions
6. **Documentation links** - Quick links to all docs
7. **Contributing & License** - Contribution guide, MIT license, author

### Files Created:
- `.auto-claude/specs/004.../implementation_plan.json` - Full implementation plan
- `.auto-claude/specs/004.../build-progress.txt` - Progress tracking

The plan is ready for implementation!
I'll start by reading the spec, implementation plan, and context files to understand what needs to be done for this subtask.

entries.detail:
1→# Quick Start Guide
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→This guide will get you up and running with the SizeWise HVAC Canvas App in 15 minutes. Follow these steps to set up your development environment, understand the project structure, and make your first contribution.
     6→
     7→## Prerequisites
     8→
     9→Before you begin, ensure you have:
    10→
    11→- **Node.js** 18.x or higher ([download](https://nodejs.org/))
    12→- **npm** or **yarn** package manager
    13→- **Git** for version control
    14→- **Rust** 1.70+ (for Tauri desktop builds - [install](https://rustup.rs/))
    15→- Code editor (VS Code recommended)
    16→
    17→## 📦 Installation (5 minutes)
    18→
    19→### 1. Clone the Repository
    20→
    21→```bash
    22→git clone https://github.com/your-org/hvac-canvas-app.git
    23→cd hvac-canvas-app
    24→```
    25→
    26→### 2. Install Dependencies
    27→
    28→```bash
    29→npm install
    30→# or
    31→yarn install
    32→```
    33→
    34→This installs:
    35→- Next.js 14 framework
    36→- React 18 with TypeScript
    37→- Zustand state management
    38→- Zod validation
    39→- Tauri desktop runtime
    40→- Vitest testing framework
    41→
    42→### 3. Set Up Environment Variables
    43→
    44→```bash
    45→cp .env.example .env.local
    46→```
    47→
    48→Edit `.env.local` if needed (most defaults work for development).
    49→
    50→### 4. Verify Installation
    51→
    52→```bash
    53→npm run dev
    54→```
    55→
    56→Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) in your browser.
    57→
    58→You should see the dashboard page with "No active projects yet".
    59→
    60→## 🎯 Your First 15 Minutes
    61→
    62→### Minute 1-3: Create Your First Project
    63→
    64→1. Click **"New Project"** button
    65→2. Fill in project details:
    66→   - Name: "My First HVAC Design"
    67→   - Client: "Test Client"
    68→   - Location: "123 Main St"
    69→3. Click **"Create"**
    70→
    71→You're now in the canvas editor!
    72→
    73→### Minute 4-7: Draw Your First Room
    74→
    75→1. Press **`R`** key (or click Room tool in toolbar)
    76→2. Click on canvas to set first corner
    77→3. Drag to set size (e.g., 20ft × 15ft)
    78→4. Release to create room
    79→
    80→The room appears with:
    81→- Blue outline
    82→- Centered name "Room 1"
    83→- Dimensions label
    84→
    85→### Minute 8-10: Inspect Room Properties
    86→
    87→1. Press **`V`** key (Select tool) or click Select icon
    88→2. Click on your room to select it
    89→3. Look at **Right Sidebar** (Inspector Panel)
    90→
    91→You'll see editable properties:
    92→- Name
    93→- Dimensions (width, height, ceiling height)
    94→- Occupancy type (office, retail, etc.)
    95→- Required ACH (air changes per hour)
    96→- Calculated CFM (cubic feet per minute)
    97→
    98→### Minute 11-13: Add a Duct
    99→
   100→1. Press **`D`** key (Duct tool)
   101→2. Click inside room to start duct
   102→3. Drag to create duct length
   103→4. Release to finish
   104→
   105→The duct shows:
   106→- Gray rounded rectangle (for round duct)
   107→- Diameter label
   108→- Airflow direction arrow
   109→- CFM value
   110→
   111→### Minute 14-15: Test Undo/Redo
   112→
   113→1. Press **`Ctrl/Cmd + Z`** to undo duct creation
   114→2. Press **`Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + Z`** to redo
   115→
   116→Notice the undo history maintains up to 100 steps.
   117→
   118→---
   119→
   120→## 🗂️ Project Structure (What Goes Where)
   121→
   122→```
   123→hvac-canvas-app/
   124→├── app/                          # Next.js 14 app directory
   125→│   ├── (main)/dashboard/         # Dashboard page
   126→│   └── (main)/canvas/[id]/       # Canvas editor (dynamic route)
   127→│
   128→├── src/
   129→│   ├── core/                     # Shared infrastructure
   130→│   │   ├── schema/               # Zod schemas (validation)
   131→│   │   ├── store/                # Zustand stores (state)
   132→│   │   ├── persistence/          # File I/O, serialization
   133→│   │   └── commands/             # Command pattern (undo/redo)
   134→│   │
   135→│   ├── features/                 # Feature modules
   136→│   │   ├── canvas/               # Canvas editor feature
   137→│   │   │   ├── components/       # Canvas UI components
   138→│   │   │   ├── tools/            # Drawing tools (Room, Duct, etc.)
   139→│   │   │   ├── renderers/        # Entity renderers
   140→│   │   │   ├── hooks/            # Canvas-specific hooks
   141→│   │   │   └── store/            # Canvas-specific state
   142→│   │   │
   143→│   │   └── dashboard/            # Dashboard feature
   144→│   │
   145→│   └── components/               # Shared UI components
   146→│       └── ui/                   # Generic primitives
   147→│
   148→├── docs/                         # Documentation
   149→│   ├── elements/                 # Element documentation
   150→│   ├── guides/                   # How-to guides
   151→│   └── ARCHITECTURE.md           # System architecture
   152→│
   153→└── tests/                        # Test files
   154→    ├── unit/                     # Unit tests
   155→    ├── integration/              # Integration tests
   156→    └── e2e/                      # Playwright E2E tests
   157→```
   158→
   159→## 🎨 Key Concepts (What Makes This App Tick)
   160→
   161→### 1. Normalized State (Performance)
   162→
   163→All entities stored by ID for O(1) lookups:
   164→
   165→```typescript
   166→// entityStore structure
   167→{
   168→  byId: {
   169→    'room-123': { id: 'room-123', type: 'room', props: {...} },
   170→    'duct-456': { id: 'duct-456', type: 'duct', props: {...} }
   171→  },
   172→  allIds: ['room-123', 'duct-456']
   173→}
   174→```
   175→
   176→### 2. Tool System (User Interactions)
   177→
   178→Each tool handles mouse/keyboard input:
   179→
   180→```typescript
   181→class RoomTool extends BaseTool {
   182→  onMouseDown(event) { /* Start drawing */ }
   183→  onMouseMove(event) { /* Show preview */ }
   184→  onMouseUp(event) { /* Create room */ }
   185→}
   186→```
   187→
   188→Tools available:
   189→- **SelectTool** - Select and move entities (`V`)
   190→- **RoomTool** - Draw rooms (`R`)
   191→- **DuctTool** - Draw ducts (`D`)
   192→- **EquipmentTool** - Place equipment (`E`)
   193→
   194→### 3. Command Pattern (Undo/Redo)
   195→
   196→Every state change wrapped in a command:
   197→
   198→```typescript
   199→// Instead of direct mutation:
   200→entityStore.addEntity(room);
   201→
   202→// Use command:
   203→createEntity(room); // Undo-able
   204→```
   205→
   206→### 4. Pure Canvas 2D Rendering
   207→
   208→No React rendering for performance:
   209→
   210→```typescript
   211→// Renders at 60fps
   212→const render = (ctx: CanvasRenderingContext2D) => {
   213→  ctx.clearRect(0, 0, width, height);
   214→  ctx.save();
   215→  ctx.translate(panX, panY);
   216→  ctx.scale(zoom, zoom);
   217→
   218→  // Render all entities
   219→  entities.forEach(entity => {
   220→    if (entity.type === 'room') renderRoom(entity, ctx);
   221→    if (entity.type === 'duct') renderDuct(entity, ctx);
   222→  });
   223→
   224→  ctx.restore();
   225→};
   226→```
   227→
   228→## 🔧 Common Development Tasks
   229→
   230→### Add a New Entity Type
   231→
   232→See [HOW_TO_ADD_ENTITY.md](./guides/HOW_TO_ADD_ENTITY.md) for step-by-step instructions.
   233→
   234→### Run Tests
   235→
   236→```bash
   237→# Unit tests (Vitest)
   238→npm run test
   239→
   240→# Watch mode
   241→npm run test:watch
   242→
   243→# E2E tests (Playwright)
   244→npm run test:e2e
   245→```
   246→
   247→### Build Desktop App
   248→
   249→```bash
   250→# Development build
   251→npm run tauri dev
   252→
   253→# Production build
   254→npm run tauri build
   255→```
   256→
   257→### Lint and Format
   258→
   259→```bash
   260→# ESLint
   261→npm run lint
   262→
   263→# Prettier
   264→npm run format
   265→
   266→# Fix all
   267→npm run lint:fix && npm run format:write
   268→```
   269→
   270→## 🐛 Debugging Tips
   271→
   272→### 1. Enable Zustand DevTools
   273→
   274→```typescript
   275→// In any store file
   276→import { devtools } from 'zustand/middleware';
   277→
   278→export const useEntityStore = create(
   279→  devtools(
   280→    (set) => ({ /* ... */ }),
   281→    { name: 'EntityStore' }
   282→  )
   283→);
   284→```
   285→
   286→Then use Redux DevTools extension in browser.
   287→
   288→### 2. Canvas Rendering Debug
   289→
   290→Add to CanvasContainer.tsx:
   291→
   292→```typescript
   293→// Show FPS counter
   294→const fps = useRef(0);
   295→const lastFrameTime = useRef(performance.now());
   296→
   297→const render = () => {
   298→  const now = performance.now();
   299→  fps.current = 1000 / (now - lastFrameTime.current);
   300→  lastFrameTime.current = now;
   301→
   302→  console.log('FPS:', fps.current.toFixed(1));
   303→  // ... rest of render
   304→};
   305→```
   306→
   307→### 3. Entity State Inspector
   308→
   309→```typescript
   310→// Add to useEffect in any component
   311→console.log('Entities:', useEntityStore.getState().byId);
   312→console.log('Selection:', useSelectionStore.getState().selectedIds);
   313→```
   314→
   315→## 📚 Next Steps
   316→
   317→Now that you're set up, dive deeper:
   318→
   319→1. **Read Architecture** → [ARCHITECTURE.md](./ARCHITECTURE.md)
   320→2. **Learn State Management** → [docs/elements/02-stores/](./elements/02-stores/)
   321→3. **Understand Tools** → [docs/elements/04-tools/](./elements/04-tools/)
   322→4. **Study Calculators** → [docs/elements/06-calculators/](./elements/06-calculators/)
   323→5. **Write Tests** → [TESTING.md](./TESTING.md)
   324→
   325→## 🎓 Learning Path
   326→
   327→### Beginner (Week 1)
   328→- [ ] Complete this Quick Start
   329→- [ ] Create and save a project
   330→- [ ] Draw rooms and ducts
   331→- [ ] Understand project structure
   332→- [ ] Read ARCHITECTURE.md
   333→
   334→### Intermediate (Week 2-3)
   335→- [ ] Add a new entity type
   336→- [ ] Write unit tests for a store
   337→- [ ] Implement a custom tool
   3

     9→
    10→## Overview
    11→
    12→SizeWise HVAC Canvas is a **modern, local-first desktop application** that empowers HVAC professionals to design, size, and estimate ventilation systems with precision and speed. Built for the real-world needs of commercial kitchen ventilation specialists, HVAC estimators, and mechanical designers, it combines intuitive visual design with powerful engineering calculations—all without requiring an internet connection or cloud subscription.
    13→
    14→### Who Is This For?
    15→
    16→- **HVAC Estimators** — Quickly lay out ductwork, calculate airflow requirements, and generate accurate Bills of Materials for bids
    17→- **Kitchen Ventilation Specialists** — Design exhaust hood systems with proper CFM calculations for commercial kitchens
    18→- **Mechanical Designers** — Create professional HVAC layouts with real-time engineering feedback
    19→- **Small to Mid-Size Contractors** — Get enterprise-level design capabilities without enterprise pricing
    20→
    21→### Why SizeWise HVAC Canvas?
    22→
    23→| Traditional Tools | SizeWise HVAC Canvas |
    24→|-------------------|----------------------|
    25→| Expensive CAD subscriptions | **Free and open source** (MIT License) |
    26→| Cloud-dependent, requires internet | **Local-first** — your data stays on your machine |
    27→| Steep learning curve | **Intuitive canvas interface** — draw rooms in seconds |
    28→| Manual calculations in spreadsheets | **Automatic HVAC calculations** — CFM, ACH, and more |
    29→| Web apps with performance issues | **Native desktop performance** — 60fps canvas rendering |
    30→
    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→

1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas Documentation
     2→
     3→Welcome to the technical documentation for the SizeWise HVAC Canvas App. This documentation is designed to help developers understand the architecture, data models, and implementation details of the application.
     4→
     5→## 🚀 Quick Start
     6→
     7→- **[Quick Start Guide](./QUICK_START.md)**: Get up and running in 15 minutes
     8→- **[System Architecture](./ARCHITECTURE.md)**: Start here to understand how the app works at a high level
     9→- **[Testing Guide](./TESTING.md)**: Comprehensive testing strategies and examples
    10→- **[Glossary](./GLOSSARY.md)**: HVAC and technical terms reference
    11→- **[Element Index](./elements/INDEX.md)**: A complete list of all components, stores, hooks, and utilities
    12→- **[Contributor Guide](../CONTRIBUTING.md)**: Setup, testing, and contribution standards
    13→- **[How to Add Entities](./guides/HOW_TO_ADD_ENTITY.md)**: Step-by-step guide for extending the system
    14→- **[User Journeys](./UserJourney.md)**: Understand the application from a user's perspective
    15→
    16→## 📁 Documentation Structure
    17→
    18→- **[`/elements`](./elements/)**: Detailed documentation for every code element.
    19→- **[`/guides`](./guides/)**: "How-to" cookbooks for common development tasks.
    20→- **[`/archive`](./archive/)**: Historical implementation plans and archived PR documentation.
    21→
    22→## 🛠 Tech Stack
    23→
    24→- **Core**: Next.js 14 (React 18), TypeScript 5, Tauri 1.x (Desktop Runtime)
    25→- **State**: Zustand (Normalized state management)
    26→- **Validation**: Zod (Runtime schema validation)
    27→- **Rendering**: Pure HTML5 Canvas 2D
    28→- **Testing**: Vitest (Unit/Integration), Playwright (E2E)
    29→
    30→## 📐 Development Standards
    31→
    32→We follow a **Feature-Slice Architecture**:
    33→1. **Core**: Shared infrastructure (schemas, persistence, math)
    34→2. **Features**: Self-contained modules (canvas, dashboard, export)
    35→3. **Components**: Generic UI primitives
    36→
    37→For details on how to document new elements, see the **[Documentation README](./elements/README.md)**.
    38→

    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→## ✨ Features
    38→
    39→### 🎨 Visual Canvas Design
    40→Draw rooms, ductwork, and equipment on an **infinite canvas** with intuitive drag-and-drop tools. See your HVAC layout come to life in real-time with 60fps rendering performance.
    41→
    42→### 📐 Automatic HVAC Calculations
    43→Let the app do the math. As you design, the **calculation engine** automatically computes:
    44→- **CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute)** — Airflow requirements based on room dimensions
    45→- **ACH (Air Changes per Hour)** — Ventilation rates for code compliance
    46→- **Duct sizing** — Proper dimensions for your specified airflow
    47→
    48→### 📦 Bill of Materials Generation
    49→Generate accurate **Bills of Materials** directly from your design. Export equipment lists, ductwork quantities, and material specifications for bidding and procurement.
    50→
    51→### 🔒 Local-First Architecture
    52→Your data **never leaves your machine**. All project files are stored locally in a validated `.sws` format—no cloud accounts, no subscriptions, no internet required.
    53→
    54→### 💻 Native Cross-Platform Desktop
    55→Built with **Tauri** for true native performance on:
    56→- ✅ Windows 10/11
    57→- ✅ macOS (Intel & Apple Silicon)
    58→- ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
    59→
    60→### ↩️ Robust Undo/Redo
    61→Made a mistake? No problem. The **command-based history system** supports up to 100 undo steps, so you can experiment freely without fear of losing work.
    62→
    63→### 🗂️ Project File Management
    64→Save your entire project as a single `.sws` file with **automatic validation**. The app creates backups automatically, ensuring your work is always protected.
    65→
    66→### 📚 Equipment Library
    67→Access a built-in library of **HVAC equipment types** including exhaust hoods, fans, and ductwork components—complete with default specifications you can customize.
    68→

1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas
     2→
     3→**Professional HVAC design and estimation desktop application for HVAC estimators, designers, and kitchen ventilation specialists.**
     4→
     5→[![CI Pipeline](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml)
     6→[![CodeQL](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml)
     7→[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     8→[![Platform](https://img.shields.io/badge/platform-Windows%20%7C%20macOS%20%7C%20Linux-lightgrey.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/releases)
     9→
    10→## Overview
    11→
    12→SizeWise HVAC Canvas is a **modern, local-first desktop application** that empowers HVAC professionals to design, size, and estimate ventilation systems with precision and speed. Built for the real-world needs of commercial kitchen ventilation specialists, HVAC estimators, and mechanical designers, it combines intuitive visual design with powerful engineering calculations—all without requiring an internet connection or cloud subscription.
    13→
    14→### Who Is This For?
    15→
    16→- **HVAC Estimators** — Quickly lay out ductwork, calculate airflow requirements, and generate accurate Bills of Materials for bids
    17→- **Kitchen Ventilation Specialists** — Design exhaust hood systems with proper CFM calculations for commercial kitchens
    18→- **Mechanical Designers** — Create professional HVAC layouts with real-time engineering feedback
    19→- **Small to Mid-Size Contractors** — Get enterprise-level design capabilities without enterprise pricing
    20→
    21→### Why SizeWise HVAC Canvas?
    22→
    23→| Traditional Tools | SizeWise HVAC Canvas |
    24→|-------------------|----------------------|
    25→| Expensive CAD subscriptions | **Free and open source** (MIT License) |
    26→| Cloud-dependent, requires internet | **Local-first** — your data stays on your machine |
    27→| Steep learning curve | **Intuitive canvas interface** — draw rooms in seconds |
    28→| Manual calculations in spreadsheets | **Automatic HVAC calculations** — CFM, ACH, and more |
    29→| Web apps with performance issues | **Native desktop performance** — 60fps canvas rendering |
    30→
    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→## ✨ Features
    38→
    39→### 🎨 Visual Canvas Design
    40→Draw rooms, ductwork, and equipment on an **infinite canvas** with intuitive drag-and-drop tools. See your HVAC layout come to life in real-time with 60fps rendering performance.
    41→
    42→### 📐 Automatic HVAC Calculations
    43→Let the app do the math. As you design, the **calculation engine** automatically computes:
    44→- **CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute)** — Airflow requirements based on room dimensions
    45→- **ACH (Air Changes per Hour)** — Ventilation rates for code compliance
    46→- **Duct sizing** — Proper dimensions for your specified airflow
    47→
    48→### 📦 Bill of Materials Generation
    49→Generate accurate **Bills of Materials** directly from your design. Export equipment lists, ductwork quantities, and material specifications for bidding and procurement.
    50→
    51→### 🔒 Local-First Architecture
    52→Your data **never leaves your machine**. All project files are stored locally in a validated `.sws` format—no cloud accounts, no subscriptions, no internet required.
    53→
    54→### 💻 Native Cross-Platform Desktop
    55→Built with **Tauri** for true native performance on:
    56→- ✅ Windows 10/11
    57→- ✅ macOS (Intel & Apple Silicon)
    58→- ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
    59→
    60→### ↩️ Robust Undo/Redo
    61→Made a mistake? No problem. The **command-based history system** supports up to 100 undo steps, so you can experiment freely without fear of losing work.
    62→
    63→### 🗂️ Project File Management
    64→Save your entire project as a single `.sws` file with **automatic validation**. The app creates backups automatically, ensuring your work is always protected.
    65→
    66→### 📚 Equipment Library
    67→Access a built-in library of **HVAC equipment types** including exhaust hoods, fans, and ductwork components—complete with default specifications you can customize.
    68→

entries.detail:
1→# Quick Start Guide
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→This guide will get you up and running with the SizeWise HVAC Canvas App in 15 minutes. Follow these steps to set up your development environment, understand the project structure, and make your first contribution.
     6→
     7→## Prerequisites
     8→
     9→Before you begin, ensure you have:
    10→
    11→- **Node.js** 18.x or higher ([download](https://nodejs.org/))
    12→- **npm** or **yarn** package manager
    13→- **Git** for version control
    14→- **Rust** 1.70+ (for Tauri desktop builds - [install](https://rustup.rs/))
    15→- Code editor (VS Code recommended)
    16→
    17→## 📦 Installation (5 minutes)
    18→
    19→### 1. Clone the Repository
    20→
    21→```bash
    22→git clone https://github.com/your-org/hvac-canvas-app.git
    23→cd hvac-canvas-app
    24→```
    25→
    26→### 2. Install Dependencies
    27→
    28→```bash
    29→npm install
    30→# or
    31→yarn install
    32→```
    33→
    34→This installs:
    35→- Next.js 14 framework
    36→- React 18 with TypeScript
    37→- Zustand state management
    38→- Zod validation
    39→- Tauri desktop runtime
    40→- Vitest testing framework
    41→
    42→### 3. Set Up Environment Variables
    43→
    44→```bash
    45→cp .env.example .env.local
    46→```
    47→
    48→Edit `.env.local` if needed (most defaults work for development).
    49→
    50→### 4. Verify Installation
    51→
    52→```bash
    53→npm run dev
    54→```
    55→
    56→Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) in your browser.
    57→
    58→You should see the dashboard page with "No active projects yet".
    59→
    60→## 🎯 Your First 15 Minutes
    61→
    62→### Minute 1-3: Create Your First Project
    63→
    64→1. Click **"New Project"** button
    65→2. Fill in project details:
    66→   - Name: "My First HVAC Design"
    67→   - Client: "Test Client"
    68→   - Location: "123 Main St"
    69→3. Click **"Create"**
    70→
    71→You're now in the canvas editor!
    72→
    73→### Minute 4-7: Draw Your First Room
    74→
    75→1. Press **`R`** key (or click Room tool in toolbar)
    76→2. Click on canvas to set first corner
    77→3. Drag to set size (e.g., 20ft × 15ft)
    78→4. Release to create room
    79→
    80→The room appears with:
    81→- Blue outline
    82→- Centered name "Room 1"
    83→- Dimensions label
    84→
    85→### Minute 8-10: Inspect Room Properties
    86→
    87→1. Press **`V`** key (Select tool) or click Select icon
    88→2. Click on your room to select it
    89→3. Look at **Right Sidebar** (Inspector Panel)
    90→
    91→You'll see editable properties:
    92→- Name
    93→- Dimensions (width, height, ceiling height)
    94→- Occupancy type (office, retail, etc.)
    95→- Required ACH (air changes per hour)
    96→- Calculated CFM (cubic feet per minute)
    97→
    98→### Minute 11-13: Add a Duct
    99→
   100→1. Press **`D`** key (Duct tool)
   101→2. Click inside room to start duct
   102→3. Drag to create duct length
   103→4. Release to finish
   104→
   105→The duct shows:
   106→- Gray rounded rectangle (for round duct)
   107→- Diameter label
   108→- Airflow direction arrow
   109→- CFM value
   110→
   111→### Minute 14-15: Test Undo/Redo
   112→
   113→1. Press **`Ctrl/Cmd + Z`** to undo duct creation
   114→2. Press **`Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + Z`** to redo
   115→
   116→Notice the undo history maintains up to 100 steps.
   117→
   118→---
   119→
   120→## 🗂️ Project Structure (What Goes Where)
   121→
   122→```
   123→hvac-canvas-app/
   124→├── app/                          # Next.js 14 app directory
   125→│   ├── (main)/dashboard/         # Dashboard page
   126→│   └── (main)/canvas/[id]/       # Canvas editor (dynamic route)
   127→│
   128→├── src/
   129→│   ├── core/                     # Shared infrastructure
   130→│   │   ├── schema/               # Zod schemas (validation)
   131→│   │   ├── store/                # Zustand stores (state)
   132→│   │   ├── persistence/          # File I/O, serialization
   133→│   │   └── commands/             # Command pattern (undo/redo)
   134→│   │
   135→│   ├── features/                 # Feature modules
   136→│   │   ├── canvas/               # Canvas editor feature
   137→│   │   │   ├── components/       # Canvas UI components
   138→│   │   │   ├── tools/            # Drawing tools (Room, Duct, etc.)
   139→│   │   │   ├── renderers/        # Entity renderers
   140→│   │   │   ├── hooks/            # Canvas-specific hooks
   141→│   │   │   └── store/            # Canvas-specific state
   142→│   │   │
   143→│   │   └── dashboard/            # Dashboard feature
   144→│   │
   145→│   └── components/               # Shared UI components
   146→│       └── ui/                   # Generic primitives
   147→│
   148→├── docs/                         # Documentation
   149→│   ├── elements/                 # Element documentation
   150→│   ├── guides/                   # How-to guides
   151→│   └── ARCHITECTURE.md           # System architecture
   152→│
   153→└── tests/                        # Test files
   154→    ├── unit/                     # Unit tests
   155→    ├── integration/              # Integration tests
   156→    └── e2e/                      # Playwright E2E tests
   157→```
   158→
   159→## 🎨 Key Concepts (What Makes This App Tick)
   160→
   161→### 1. Normalized State (Performance)
   162→
   163→All entities stored by ID for O(1) lookups:
   164→
   165→```typescript
   166→// entityStore structure
   167→{
   168→  byId: {
   169→    'room-123': { id: 'room-123', type: 'room', props: {...} },
   170→    'duct-456': { id: 'duct-456', type: 'duct', props: {...} }
   171→  },
   172→  allIds: ['room-123', 'duct-456']
   173→}
   174→```
   175→
   176→### 2. Tool System (User Interactions)
   177→
   178→Each tool handles mouse/keyboard input:
   179→
   180→```typescript
   181→class RoomTool extends BaseTool {
   182→  onMouseDown(event) { /* Start drawing */ }
   183→  onMouseMove(event) { /* Show preview */ }
   184→  onMouseUp(event) { /* Create room */ }
   185→}
   186→```
   187→
   188→Tools available:
   189→- **SelectTool** - Select and move entities (`V`)
   190→- **RoomTool** - Draw rooms (`R`)
   191→- **DuctTool** - Draw ducts (`D`)
   192→- **EquipmentTool** - Place equipment (`E`)
   193→
   194→### 3. Command Pattern (Undo/Redo)
   195→
   196→Every state change wrapped in a command:
   197→
   198→```typescript
   199→// Instead of direct mutation:
   200→entityStore.addEntity(room);
   201→
   202→// Use command:
   203→createEntity(room); // Undo-able
   204→```
   205→
   206→### 4. Pure Canvas 2D Rendering
   207→
   208→No React rendering for performance:
   209→
   210→```typescript
   211→// Renders at 60fps
   212→const render = (ctx: CanvasRenderingContext2D) => {
   213→  ctx.clearRect(0, 0, width, height);
   214→  ctx.save();
   215→  ctx.translate(panX, panY);
   216→  ctx.scale(zoom, zoom);
   217→
   218→  // Render all entities
   219→  entities.forEach(entity => {
   220→    if (entity.type === 'room') renderRoom(entity, ctx);
   221→    if (entity.type === 'duct') renderDuct(entity, ctx);
   222→  });
   223→
   224→  ctx.restore();
   225→};
   226→```
   227→
   228→## 🔧 Common Development Tasks
   229→
   230→### Add a New Entity Type
   231→
   232→See [HOW_TO_ADD_ENTITY.md](./guides/HOW_TO_ADD_ENTITY.md) for step-by-step instructions.
   233→
   234→### Run Tests
   235→
   236→```bash
   237→# Unit tests (Vitest)
   238→npm run test
   239→
   240→# Watch mode
   241→npm run test:watch
   242→
   243→# E2E tests (Playwright)
   244→npm run test:e2e
   245→```
   246→
   247→### Build Desktop App
   248→
   249→```bash
   250→# Development build
   251→npm run tauri dev
   252→
   253→# Production build
   254→npm run tauri build
   255→```
   256→
   257→### Lint and Format
   258→
   259→```bash
   260→# ESLint
   261→npm run lint
   262→
   263→# Prettier
   264→npm run format
   265→
   266→# Fix all
   267→npm run lint:fix && npm run format:write
   268→```
   269→
   270→## 🐛 Debugging Tips
   271→
   272→### 1. Enable Zustand DevTools
   273→
   274→```typescript
   275→// In any store file
   276→import { devtools } from 'zustand/middleware';
   277→
   278→export const useEntityStore = create(
   279→  devtools(
   280→    (set) => ({ /* ... */ }),
   281→    { name: 'EntityStore' }
   282→  )
   283→);
   284→```
   285→

1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas
     2→
     3→**Professional HVAC design and estimation desktop application for HVAC estimators, designers, and kitchen ventilation specialists.**
     4→
     5→[![CI Pipeline](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml)
     6→[![CodeQL](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml)
     7→[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     8→[![Platform](https://img.shields.io/badge/platform-Windows%20%7C%20macOS%20%7C%20Linux-lightgrey.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/releases)
     9→
    10→## Overview
    11→
    12→SizeWise HVAC Canvas is a **modern, local-first desktop application** that empowers HVAC professionals to design, size, and estimate ventilation systems with precision and speed. Built for the real-world needs of commercial kitchen ventilation specialists, HVAC estimators, and mechanical designers, it combines intuitive visual design with powerful engineering calculations—all without requiring an internet connection or cloud subscription.
    13→
    14→### Who Is This For?
    15→
    16→- **HVAC Estimators** — Quickly lay out ductwork, calculate airflow requirements, and generate accurate Bills of Materials for bids
    17→- **Kitchen Ventilation Specialists** — Design exhaust hood systems with proper CFM calculations for commercial kitchens
    18→- **Mechanical Designers** — Create professional HVAC layouts with real-time engineering feedback
    19→- **Small to Mid-Size Contractors** — Get enterprise-level design capabilities without enterprise pricing
    20→
    21→### Why SizeWise HVAC Canvas?
    22→
    23→| Traditional Tools | SizeWise HVAC Canvas |
    24→|-------------------|----------------------|
    25→| Expensive CAD subscriptions | **Free and open source** (MIT License) |
    26→| Cloud-dependent, requires internet | **Local-first** — your data stays on your machine |
    27→| Steep learning curve | **Intuitive canvas interface** — draw rooms in seconds |
    28→| Manual calculations in spreadsheets | **Automatic HVAC calculations** — CFM, ACH, and more |
    29→| Web apps with performance issues | **Native desktop performance** — 60fps canvas rendering |
    30→
    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→## ✨ Features
    38→
    39→### 🎨 Visual Canvas Design
    40→Draw rooms, ductwork, and equipment on an **infinite canvas** with intuitive drag-and-drop tools. See your HVAC layout come to life in real-time with 60fps rendering performance.
    41→
    42→### 📐 Automatic HVAC Calculations
    43→Let the app do the math. As you design, the **calculation engine** automatically computes:
    44→- **CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute)** — Airflow requirements based on room dimensions
    45→- **ACH (Air Changes per Hour)** — Ventilation rates for code compliance
    46→- **Duct sizing** — Proper dimensions for your specified airflow
    47→
    48→### 📦 Bill of Materials Generation
    49→Generate accurate **Bills of Materials** directly from your design. Export equipment lists, ductwork quantities, and material specifications for bidding and procurement.
    50→
    51→### 🔒 Local-First Architecture
    52→Your data **never leaves your machine**. All project files are stored locally in a validated `.sws` format—no cloud accounts, no subscriptions, no internet required.
    53→
    54→### 💻 Native Cross-Platform Desktop
    55→Built with **Tauri** for true native performance on:
    56→- ✅ Windows 10/11
    57→- ✅ macOS (Intel & Apple Silicon)
    58→- ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
    59→
    60→### ↩️ Robust Undo/Redo
    61→Made a mistake? No problem. The **command-based history system** supports up to 100 undo steps, so you can experiment freely without fear of losing work.
    62→
    63→### 🗂️ Project File Management
    64→Save your entire project as a single `.sws` file with **automatic validation**. The app creates backups automatically, ensuring your work is always protected.
    65→
    66→### 📚 Equipment Library
    67→Access a built-in library of **HVAC equipment types** including exhaust hoods, fans, and ductwork components—complete with default specifications you can customize.
    68→
    69→## 🚀 Quick Start
    70→
    71→### Prerequisites
    72→
    73→Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:
    74→
    75→| Requirement | Version | Installation |
    76→|-------------|---------|--------------|
    77→| **Node.js** | 18.0.0+ | [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org/) |
    78→| **Rust** | 1.70.0+ | [rustup.rs](https://rustup.rs/) |
    79→| **npm** | 9.0.0+ | Included with Node.js |
    80→| **Git** | Latest | [git-scm.com](https://git-scm.com/) |
    81→
    82→### Installation
    83→
    84→```bash
    85→# Clone the repository
    86→git clone https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App.git
    87→cd HVAC_Canvas_App/hvac-design-app
    88→
    89→# Install dependencies
    90→npm install
    91→```
    92→
    93→### Development
    94→
    95→```bash
    96→# Start the web development server
    97→npm run dev
    98→# Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
    99→
   100→# Or run the full desktop app in dev mode
   101→npm run tauri:dev
   102→```
   103→
   104→### Build for Production
   105→
   106→```bash
   107→# Build the desktop application
   108→npm run tauri:build
   109→# Output: src-tauri/target/release/
   110→```
   111→
   112→> 📖 **Need more details?** See the full [Quick Start Guide](docs/QUICK_START.md) for step-by-step instructions, debugging tips, and your first 15 minutes with the app.
   113→
   114→

## ✅ Subtask 2.5 Completed Successfully

### Summary

I've added a comprehensive **Tech Stack** section to the README.md with the following content:

#### Content Added
The section organizes the technology stack into 6 categories with tables showing technology name, version, and purpose:

1. **Core Framework**: Next.js 15.0, React 18.2, Tauri 1.x, Rust 2021 Edition, TypeScript 5.3
2. **State Management**: Zustand 4.4, Immer 11.0

1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas Documentation
     2→
     3→Welcome to the technical documentation for the SizeWise HVAC Canvas App. This documentation is designed to help developers understand the architecture, data models, and implementation details of the application.
     4→
     5→## 🚀 Quick Start
     6→
     7→- **[Quick Start Guide](./QUICK_START.md)**: Get up and running in 15 minutes
     8→- **[System Architecture](./ARCHITECTURE.md)**: Start here to understand how the app works at a high level
     9→- **[Testing Guide](./TESTING.md)**: Comprehensive testing strategies and examples
    10→- **[Glossary](./GLOSSARY.md)**: HVAC and technical terms reference
    11→- **[Element Index](./elements/INDEX.md)**: A complete list of all components, stores, hooks, and utilities
    12→- **[Contributor Guide](../CONTRIBUTING.md)**: Setup, testing, and contribution standards
    13→- **[How to Add Entities](./guides/HOW_TO_ADD_ENTITY.md)**: Step-by-step guide for extending the system
    14→- **[User Journeys](./UserJourney.md)**: Understand the application from a user's perspective
    15→
    16→## 📁 Documentation Structure
    17→
    18→- **[`/elements`](./elements/)**: Detailed documentation for every code element.
    19→- **[`/guides`](./guides/)**: "How-to" cookbooks for common development tasks.
    20→- **[`/archive`](./archive/)**: Historical implementation plans and archived PR documentation.
    21→
    22→## 🛠 Tech Stack
    23→
    24→- **Core**: Next.js 14 (React 18), TypeScript 5, Tauri 1.x (Desktop Runtime)
    25→- **State**: Zustand (Normalized state management)
    26→- **Validation**: Zod (Runtime schema validation)
    27→- **Rendering**: Pure HTML5 Canvas 2D
    28→- **Testing**: Vitest (Unit/Integration), Playwright (E2E)
    29→
    30→## 📐 Development Standards
    31→
    32→We follow a **Feature-Slice Architecture**:
    33→1. **Core**: Shared infrastructure (schemas, persistence, math)
    34→2. **Features**: Self-contained modules (canvas, dashboard, export)
    35→3. **Components**: Generic UI primitives
    36→
    37→For details on how to document new elements, see the **[Documentation README](./elements/README.md)**.
    38→

entries.detail:
1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas
     2→
     3→**Professional HVAC design and estimation desktop application for HVAC estimators, designers, and kitchen ventilation specialists.**
     4→
     5→[![CI Pipeline](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml)
     6→[![CodeQL](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml)
     7→[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     8→[![Platform](https://img.shields.io/badge/platform-Windows%20%7C%20macOS%20%7C%20Linux-lightgrey.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/releases)
     9→
    10→## Overview
    11→
    12→SizeWise HVAC Canvas is a **modern, local-first desktop application** that empowers HVAC professionals to design, size, and estimate ventilation systems with precision and speed. Built for the real-world needs of commercial kitchen ventilation specialists, HVAC estimators, and mechanical designers, it combines intuitive visual design with powerful engineering calculations—all without requiring an internet connection or cloud subscription.
    13→
    14→### Who Is This For?
    15→
    16→- **HVAC Estimators** — Quickly lay out ductwork, calculate airflow requirements, and generate accurate Bills of Materials for bids
    17→- **Kitchen Ventilation Specialists** — Design exhaust hood systems with proper CFM calculations for commercial kitchens
    18→- **Mechanical Designers** — Create professional HVAC layouts with real-time engineering feedback
    19→- **Small to Mid-Size Contractors** — Get enterprise-level design capabilities without enterprise pricing
    20→
    21→### Why SizeWise HVAC Canvas?
    22→
    23→| Traditional Tools | SizeWise HVAC Canvas |
    24→|-------------------|----------------------|
    25→| Expensive CAD subscriptions | **Free and open source** (MIT License) |
    26→| Cloud-dependent, requires internet | **Local-first** — your data stays on your machine |
    27→| Steep learning curve | **Intuitive canvas interface** — draw rooms in seconds |
    28→| Manual calculations in spreadsheets | **Automatic HVAC calculations** — CFM, ACH, and more |
    29→| Web apps with performance issues | **Native desktop performance** — 60fps canvas rendering |
    30→
    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→## ✨ Features
    38→
    39→### 🎨 Visual Canvas Design
    40→Draw rooms, ductwork, and equipment on an **infinite canvas** with intuitive drag-and-drop tools. See your HVAC layout come to life in real-time with 60fps rendering performance.
    41→
    42→### 📐 Automatic HVAC Calculations
    43→Let the app do the math. As you design, the **calculation engine** automatically computes:
    44→- **CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute)** — Airflow requirements based on room dimensions
    45→- **ACH (Air Changes per Hour)** — Ventilation rates for code compliance
    46→- **Duct sizing** — Proper dimensions for your specified airflow
    47→
    48→### 📦 Bill of Materials Generation
    49→Generate accurate **Bills of Materials** directly from your design. Export equipment lists, ductwork quantities, and material specifications for bidding and procurement.
    50→
    51→### 🔒 Local-First Architecture
    52→Your data **never leaves your machine**. All project files are stored locally in a validated `.sws` format—no cloud accounts, no subscriptions, no internet required.
    53→
    54→### 💻 Native Cross-Platform Desktop
    55→Built with **Tauri** for true native performance on:
    56→- ✅ Windows 10/11
    57→- ✅ macOS (Intel & Apple Silicon)
    58→- ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
    59→
    60→### ↩️ Robust Undo/Redo
    61→Made a mistake? No problem. The **command-based history system** supports up to 100 undo steps, so you can experiment freely without fear of losing work.
    62→
    63→### 🗂️ Project File Management
    64→Save your entire project as a single `.sws` file with **automatic validation**. The app creates backups automatically, ensuring your work is always protected.
    65→
    66→### 📚 Equipment Library
    67→Access a built-in library of **HVAC equipment types** including exhaust hoods, fans, and ductwork components—complete with default specifications you can customize.
    68→
    69→## 🚀 Quick Start
    70→
    71→### Prerequisites
    72→
    73→Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:
    74→
    75→| Requirement | Version | Installation |
    76→|-------------|---------|--------------|
    77→| **Node.js** | 18.0.0+ | [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org/) |
    78→| **Rust** | 1.70.0+ | [rustup.rs](https://rustup.rs/) |
    79→| **npm** | 9.0.0+ | Included with Node.js |
    80→| **Git** | Latest | [git-scm.com](https://git-scm.com/) |
    81→
    82→### Installation
    83→
    84→```bash
    85→# Clone the repository
    86→git clone https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App.git
    87→cd HVAC_Canvas_App/hvac-design-app
    88→
    89→# Install dependencies
    90→npm install
    91→```
    92→
    93→### Development
    94→
    95→```bash
    96→# Start the web development server
    97→npm run dev
    98→# Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
    99→
   100→# Or run the full desktop app in dev mode
   101→npm run tauri:dev
   102→```
   103→
   104→### Build for Production
   105→
   106→```bash
   107→# Build the desktop application
   108→npm run tauri:build
   109→# Output: src-tauri/target/release/
   110→```
   111→
   112→> 📖 **Need more details?** See the full [Quick Start Guide](docs/QUICK_START.md) for step-by-step instructions, debugging tips, and your first 15 minutes with the app.
   113→
   114→## 🛠️ Tech Stack
   115→
   116→### Core Framework
   117→
   118→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   119→|------------|---------|---------|
   120→| **[Next.js](https://nextjs.org/)** | 15.0 | React framework with SSR, routing, and optimizations |
   121→| **[React](https://react.dev/)** | 18.2 | UI component library |
   122→| **[Tauri](https://tauri.app/)** | 1.x | Native desktop wrapper (Rust-based, lightweight) |
   123→| **[Rust](https://www.rust-lang.org/)** | 2021 Edition | Backend runtime for native file system access |
   124→| **[TypeScript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/)** | 5.3 | Type-safe JavaScript |
   125→
   126→### State Management
   127→
   128→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   129→|------------|---------|---------|
   130→| **[Zustand](https://zustand-demo.pmnd.rs/)** | 4.4 | Lightweight, performant state management |
   131→| **[Immer](https://immerjs.github.io/immer/)** | 11.0 | Immutable state updates with mutable syntax |
   132→
   133→### UI & Styling
   134→
   135→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   136→|------------|---------|---------|
   137→| **[Material UI](https://mui.com/)** | 5.15 | React component library |
   138→| **[Emotion](https://emotion.sh/)** | 11.11 | CSS-in-JS styling solution |
   139→

entries.detail:
1→# Contributing to SizeWise HVAC Canvas App
     2→
     3→Thank you for your interest in contributing! This document provides guidelines for setting up your environment and submitting contributions.
     4→
     5→## 🚀 Getting Started
     6→
     7→### Prerequisites
     8→- **Node.js**: v18.x or higher
     9→- **Package Manager**: pnpm (v8.x recommended)
    10→- **Rust**: Required for Tauri (see [tauri.app](https://tauri.app/v1/guides/getting-started/prerequisites))
    11→
    12→### Installation
    13→1. Clone the repository:
    14→   ```bash
    15→   git clone https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App.git
    16→   cd hvac-design-app
    17→   ```
    18→
    19→2. Install dependencies:
    20→   ```bash
    21→   pnpm install
    22→   ```
    23→
    24→3. Start the development server:
    25→   ```bash
    26→   pnpm dev
    27→   ```
    28→
    29→## 📐 Development Workflow
    30→
    31→### Branch Naming
    32→Use the following prefixes for your branches:
    33→- `feat/`: New features (e.g., `feat/add-curved-ducts`)
    34→- `fix/`: Bug fixes (e.g., `fix/canvas-zoom-glitch`)
    35→- `docs/`: Documentation updates
    36→- `refactor/`: Code restructuring without behavior change
    37→- `test/`: Adding missing tests
    38→
    39→### Commit Messages
    40→We follow the [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/) specification:
    41→- `feat: add room tool`
    42→- `fix: correct ventilation calculation formula`
    43→- `docs: update architecture diagram`
    44→
    45→## 🧪 Testing
    46→
    47→We have a high standard for testing. Please ensure your changes are verified.
    48→
    49→### Unit & Integration Tests (Vitest)
    50→Run unit tests for logic, hooks, and stores:
    51→```bash
    52→pnpm test
    53→```
    54→
    55→### End-to-End Tests (Playwright)
    56→Run E2E tests for user flows:
    57→```bash
    58→pnpm test:e2e
    59→```
    60→
    61→## 📝 Code Standards
    62→
    63→- **Formatting**: We use Prettier. Run `pnpm format` before committing.
    64→- **Linting**: We use ESLint. Run `pnpm lint` to check for issues.
    65→- **Documentation**: New components/stores must be documented in `docs/elements/`.
    66→
    67→## 📁 Project Structure
    68→
    69→See [docs/README.md](docs/README.md) and [docs/ARCHITECTURE.md](docs/ARCHITECTURE.md) for a deep dive into the system architecture.
    70→

entries.detail:
1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas
     2→
     3→**Professional HVAC design and estimation desktop application for HVAC estimators, designers, and kitchen ventilation specialists.**
     4→
     5→[![CI Pipeline](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml)
     6→[![CodeQL](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml)
     7→[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     8→[![Platform](https://img.shields.io/badge/platform-Windows%20%7C%20macOS%20%7C%20Linux-lightgrey.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/releases)
     9→
    10→## Overview
    11→
    12→SizeWise HVAC Canvas is a **modern, local-first desktop application** that empowers HVAC professionals to design, size, and estimate ventilation systems with precision and speed. Built for the real-world needs of commercial kitchen ventilation specialists, HVAC estimators, and mechanical designers, it combines intuitive visual design with powerful engineering calculations—all without requiring an internet connection or cloud subscription.
    13→
    14→### Who Is This For?
    15→
    16→- **HVAC Estimators** — Quickly lay out ductwork, calculate airflow requirements, and generate accurate Bills of Materials for bids
    17→- **Kitchen Ventilation Specialists** — Design exhaust hood systems with proper CFM calculations for commercial kitchens
    18→- **Mechanical Designers** — Create professional HVAC layouts with real-time engineering feedback
    19→- **Small to Mid-Size Contractors** — Get enterprise-level design capabilities without enterprise pricing
    20→
    21→### Why SizeWise HVAC Canvas?
    22→
    23→| Traditional Tools | SizeWise HVAC Canvas |
    24→|-------------------|----------------------|
    25→| Expensive CAD subscriptions | **Free and open source** (MIT License) |
    26→| Cloud-dependent, requires internet | **Local-first** — your data stays on your machine |
    27→| Steep learning curve | **Intuitive canvas interface** — draw rooms in seconds |
    28→| Manual calculations in spreadsheets | **Automatic HVAC calculations** — CFM, ACH, and more |
    29→| Web apps with performance issues | **Native desktop performance** — 60fps canvas rendering |
    30→
    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→## ✨ Features
    38→
    39→### 🎨 Visual Canvas Design
    40→Draw rooms, ductwork, and equipment on an **infinite canvas** with intuitive drag-and-drop tools. See your HVAC layout come to life in real-time with 60fps rendering performance.
    41→
    42→### 📐 Automatic HVAC Calculations
    43→Let the app do the math. As you design, the **calculation engine** automatically computes:
    44→- **CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute)** — Airflow requirements based on room dimensions
    45→- **ACH (Air Changes per Hour)** — Ventilation rates for code compliance
    46→- **Duct sizing** — Proper dimensions for your specified airflow
    47→
    48→### 📦 Bill of Materials Generation
    49→Generate accurate **Bills of Materials** directly from your design. Export equipment lists, ductwork quantities, and material specifications for bidding and procurement.
    50→
    51→### 🔒 Local-First Architecture
    52→Your data **never leaves your machine**. All project files are stored locally in a validated `.sws` format—no cloud accounts, no subscriptions, no internet required.
    53→
    54→### 💻 Native Cross-Platform Desktop
    55→Built with **Tauri** for true native performance on:
    56→- ✅ Windows 10/11
    57→- ✅ macOS (Intel & Apple Silicon)
    58→- ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
    59→
    60→### ↩️ Robust Undo/Redo
    61→Made a mistake? No problem. The **command-based history system** supports up to 100 undo steps, so you can experiment freely without fear of losing work.
    62→
    63→### 🗂️ Project File Management
    64→Save your entire project as a single `.sws` file with **automatic validation**. The app creates backups automatically, ensuring your work is always protected.
    65→
    66→### 📚 Equipment Library
    67→Access a built-in library of **HVAC equipment types** including exhaust hoods, fans, and ductwork components—complete with default specifications you can customize.
    68→
    69→## 🚀 Quick Start
    70→
    71→### Prerequisites
    72→
    73→Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:
    74→
    75→| Requirement | Version | Installation |
    76→|-------------|---------|--------------|
    77→| **Node.js** | 18.0.0+ | [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org/) |
    78→| **Rust** | 1.70.0+ | [rustup.rs](https://rustup.rs/) |
    79→| **npm** | 9.0.0+ | Included with Node.js |
    80→| **Git** | Latest | [git-scm.com](https://git-scm.com/) |
    81→
    82→### Installation
    83→
    84→```bash
    85→# Clone the repository
    86→git clone https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App.git
    87→cd HVAC_Canvas_App/hvac-design-app
    88→
    89→# Install dependencies
    90→npm install
    91→```
    92→
    93→### Development
    94→
    95→```bash
    96→# Start the web development server
    97→npm run dev
    98→# Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
    99→
   100→# Or run the full desktop app in dev mode
   101→npm run tauri:dev
   102→```
   103→
   104→### Build for Production
   105→
   106→```bash
   107→# Build the desktop application
   108→npm run tauri:build
   109→# Output: src-tauri/target/release/
   110→```
   111→
   112→> 📖 **Need more details?** See the full [Quick Start Guide](docs/QUICK_START.md) for step-by-step instructions, debugging tips, and your first 15 minutes with the app.
   113→
   114→## 🛠️ Tech Stack
   115→
   116→### Core Framework
   117→
   118→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   119→|------------|---------|---------|
   120→| **[Next.js](https://nextjs.org/)** | 15.0 | React framework with SSR, routing, and optimizations |
   121→| **[React](https://react.dev/)** | 18.2 | UI component library |
   122→| **[Tauri](https://tauri.app/)** | 1.x | Native desktop wrapper (Rust-based, lightweight) |
   123→| **[Rust](https://www.rust-lang.org/)** | 2021 Edition | Backend runtime for native file system access |
   124→| **[TypeScript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/)** | 5.3 | Type-safe JavaScript |
   125→
   126→### State Management
   127→
   128→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   129→|------------|---------|---------|
   130→| **[Zustand](https://zustand-demo.pmnd.rs/)** | 4.4 | Lightweight, performant state management |
   131→| **[Immer](https://immerjs.github.io/immer/)** | 11.0 | Immutable state updates with mutable syntax |
   132→
   133→### UI & Styling
   134→
   135→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   136→|------------|---------|---------|
   137→| **[Material UI](https://mui.com/)** | 5.15 | React component library |
   138→| **[Emotion](https://emotion.sh/)** | 11.11 | CSS-in-JS styling solution |
   139→
   140→### Data Validation & Utilities
   141→
   142→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   143→|------------|---------|---------|
   144→| **[Zod](https://zod.dev/)** | 4.2 | Schema validation for project files |
   145→| **[nanoid](https://github.com/ai/nanoid)** | 5.1 | Unique ID generation |
   146→
   147→### Testing
   148→
   149→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   150→|------------|---------|---------|
   151→| **[Vitest](https://vitest.dev/)** | 1.6 | Unit and integration testing |
   152→| **[Testing Library](https://testing-library.com/)** | 16.3 | React component testing utilities |
   153→| **[Playwright](https://playwright.dev/)** | 1.40 | End-to-end browser testing |
   154→
   155→### Development Tools
   156→
   157→| Technology | Version | Purpose |
   158→|------------|---------|---------|
   159→| **[ESLint](https://eslint.org/)** | 8.56 | Code linting |
   160→| **[Prettier](https://prettier.io/)** | 3.1 | Code formatting |
   161→| **[Husky](https://typicode.github.io/husky/)** | 9.1 | Git hooks for pre-commit checks |
   162→
   163→## 📖 Documentation
   164→
   165→### Getting Started
   166→
   167→| Document | Description |
   168→|----------|-------------|
   169→| **[Quick Start Guide](docs/QUICK_START.md)** | Get up and running in 15 minutes |
   170→| **[Architecture Overview](docs/ARCHITECTURE.md)** | Understand the system design and data flow |
   171→| **[User Journeys](docs/UserJourney.md)** | See the app from a user's perspective |
   172→
   173→### For Contributors
   174→
   175→| Document | Description |
   176→|----------|-------------|

1→# SizeWise HVAC Canvas
     2→
     3→**Professional HVAC design and estimation desktop application for HVAC estimators, designers, and kitchen ventilation specialists.**
     4→
     5→[![CI Pipeline](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/ci.yml)
     6→[![CodeQL](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/actions/workflows/codeql.yml)
     7→[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     8→[![Platform](https://img.shields.io/badge/platform-Windows%20%7C%20macOS%20%7C%20Linux-lightgrey.svg)](https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App/releases)
     9→
    10→## Overview
    11→
    12→SizeWise HVAC Canvas is a **modern, local-first desktop application** that empowers HVAC professionals to design, size, and estimate ventilation systems with precision and speed. Built for the real-world needs of commercial kitchen ventilation specialists, HVAC estimators, and mechanical designers, it combines intuitive visual design with powerful engineering calculations—all without requiring an internet connection or cloud subscription.
    13→
    14→### Who Is This For?
    15→
    16→- **HVAC Estimators** — Quickly lay out ductwork, calculate airflow requirements, and generate accurate Bills of Materials for bids
    17→- **Kitchen Ventilation Specialists** — Design exhaust hood systems with proper CFM calculations for commercial kitchens
    18→- **Mechanical Designers** — Create professional HVAC layouts with real-time engineering feedback
    19→- **Small to Mid-Size Contractors** — Get enterprise-level design capabilities without enterprise pricing
    20→
    21→### Why SizeWise HVAC Canvas?
    22→
    23→| Traditional Tools | SizeWise HVAC Canvas |
    24→|-------------------|----------------------|
    25→| Expensive CAD subscriptions | **Free and open source** (MIT License) |
    26→| Cloud-dependent, requires internet | **Local-first** — your data stays on your machine |
    27→| Steep learning curve | **Intuitive canvas interface** — draw rooms in seconds |
    28→| Manual calculations in spreadsheets | **Automatic HVAC calculations** — CFM, ACH, and more |
    29→| Web apps with performance issues | **Native desktop performance** — 60fps canvas rendering |
    30→
    31→### Key Value Proposition
    32→
    33→> **Design faster. Calculate automatically. Own your data.**
    34→
    35→SizeWise HVAC Canvas bridges the gap between complex CAD software and simple diagramming tools, delivering a purpose-built solution for HVAC layout and estimation. The application runs entirely on your local machine, ensuring your project files and client data never leave your control—critical for contractors handling sensitive commercial projects.
    36→
    37→## ✨ Features
    38→
    39→### 🎨 Visual Canvas Design
    40→Draw rooms, ductwork, and equipment on an **infinite canvas** with intuitive drag-and-drop tools. See your HVAC layout come to life in real-time with 60fps rendering performance.
    41→
    42→### 📐 Automatic HVAC Calculations
    43→Let the app do the math. As you design, the **calculation engine** automatically computes:
    44→- **CFM (Cubic Feet per Minute)** — Airflow requirements based on room dimensions
    45→- **ACH (Air Changes per Hour)** — Ventilation rates for code compliance
    46→- **Duct sizing** — Proper dimensions for your specified airflow
    47→
    48→### 📦 Bill of Materials Generation
    49→Generate accurate **Bills of Materials** directly from your design. Export equipment lists, ductwork quantities, and material specifications for bidding and procurement.
    50→
    51→### 🔒 Local-First Architecture
    52→Your data **never leaves your machine**. All project files are stored locally in a validated `.sws` format—no cloud accounts, no subscriptions, no internet required.
    53→
    54→### 💻 Native Cross-Platform Desktop
    55→Built with **Tauri** for true native performance on:
    56→- ✅ Windows 10/11
    57→- ✅ macOS (Intel & Apple Silicon)
    58→- ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)
    59→
    60→### ↩️ Robust Undo/Redo
    61→Made a mistake? No problem. The **command-based history system** supports up to 100 undo steps, so you can experiment freely without fear of losing work.
    62→
    63→### 🗂️ Project File Management
    64→Save your entire project as a single `.sws` file with **automatic validation**. The app creates backups automatically, ensuring your work is always protected.
    65→
    66→### 📚 Equipment Library
    67→Access a built-in library of **HVAC equipment types** including exhaust hoods, fans, and ductwork components—complete with default specifications you can customize.
    68→
    69→## 🚀 Quick Start
    70→
    71→### Prerequisites
    72→
    73→Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:
    74→
    75→| Requirement | Version | Installation |
    76→|-------------|---------|--------------|
    77→| **Node.js** | 18.0.0+ | [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org/) |
    78→| **Rust** | 1.70.0+ | [rustup.rs](https://rustup.rs/) |
    79→| **npm** | 9.0.0+ | Included with Node.js |
    80→| **Git** | Latest | [git-scm.com](https://git-scm.com/) |
    81→
    82→### Installation
    83→
    84→```bash
    85→# Clone the repository
    86→git clone https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App.git
    87→cd HVAC_Canvas_App/hvac-design-app
    88→
    89→# Install dependencies
    90→npm install
    91→```
    92→
    93→### Development
    94→
    95→```bash
    96→# Start the web development server
    97→npm run dev
    98→# Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
    99→
   100→# Or run the full desktop app in dev mode
   101→npm run tauri:dev
   102→```
   103→
   104→### Build for Production
   105→
   106→```bash
   107→# Build the desktop application
   108→npm run tauri:build
   109→# Output: src-tauri/target/release/
   110→```

1→# Contributing to SizeWise HVAC Canvas App
     2→
     3→Thank you for your interest in contributing! This document provides guidelines for setting up your environment and submitting contributions.
     4→
     5→## 🚀 Getting Started
     6→
     7→### Prerequisites
     8→- **Node.js**: v18.x or higher
     9→- **Package Manager**: pnpm (v8.x recommended)
    10→- **Rust**: Required for Tauri (see [tauri.app](https://tauri.app/v1/guides/getting-started/prerequisites))
    11→
    12→### Installation
    13→1. Clone the repository:
    14→   ```bash
    15→   git clone https://github.com/engryamato/HVAC_Canvas_App.git
    16→   cd hvac-design-app
    17→   ```
    18→
    19→2. Install dependencies:
    20→   ```bash
    21→   pnpm install
    22→   ```
    23→
    24→3. Start the development server:
    25→   ```bash
    26→   pnpm dev
    27→   ```
    28→
    29→## 📐 Development Workflow
    30→
    31→### Branch Naming
    32→Use the following prefixes for your branches:
    33→- `feat/`: New features (e.g., `feat/add-curved-ducts`)
    34→- `fix/`: Bug fixes (e.g., `fix/canvas-zoom-glitch`)
    35→- `docs/`: Documentation updates
    36→- `refactor/`: Code restructuring without behavior change
    37→- `test/`: Adding missing tests
    38→
    39→### Commit Messages
    40→We follow the [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/) specification:
    41→- `feat: add room tool`
    42→- `fix: correct ventilation calculation formula`
    43→- `docs: update architecture diagram`
    44→
    45→## 🧪 Testing
    46→
    47→We have a high standard for testing. Please ensure your changes are verified.
    48→
    49→### Unit & Integration Tests (Vitest)
    50→Run unit tests for logic, hooks, and stores:
    51→```bash
    52→pnpm test
    53→```
    54→
    55→### End-to-End Tests (Playwright)
    56→Run E2E tests for user flows:
    57→```bash
    58→pnpm test:e2e
    59→```
    60→
    61→## 📝 Code Standards
    62→
    63→- **Formatting**: We use Prettier. Run `pnpm format` before committing.
    64→- **Linting**: We use ESLint. Run `pnpm lint` to check for issues.
    65→- **Documentation**: New components/stores must be documented in `docs/elements/`.
    66→
    67→## 📁 Project Structure
    68→
    69→See [docs/README.md](docs/README.md) and [docs/ARCHITECTURE.md](docs/ARCHITECTURE.md) for a deep dive into the system architecture.
    70→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>
